channel.title: Comments on: Grammatical Interlude: The Two Acceptable Uses of Quotation Marks

item.title: By: Amy Leskowski
item.dc:creator: Amy Leskowski
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/scarequotes/#comment-523931">Daniel Reeves</a>.
Thank you, Daniel! Wow, I didn't know if I'd get a response as this seemed like an old post! Thank you :)
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Daniel Reeves.

Thank you, Daniel! Wow, I didn’t know if I’d get a response as this seemed like an old post! Thank you :)

item.title: By: Daniel Reeves
item.dc:creator: Daniel Reeves
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/scarequotes/#comment-523930">Amy Leskowski</a>.
Not necessary there! "Old soul" isn't the father's coinage. Kind of like how "my roommate called me a deadbeat" doesn't want quotes around "deadbeat" even if my roommate literally called me that.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Amy Leskowski.

Not necessary there! “Old soul” isn’t the father’s coinage. Kind of like how “my roommate called me a deadbeat” doesn’t want quotes around “deadbeat” even if my roommate literally called me that.

item.title: By: Amy Leskowski
item.dc:creator: Amy Leskowski
item.description:
I'm wandering around the internet trying to figure out if it's acceptable to use scare quotes in this situation:
He has what his father calls an old soul.
Should it be:
He has what his father calls "an old soul."
item.content:encoded:
I’m wandering around the internet trying to figure out if it’s acceptable to use scare quotes in this situation:

He has what his father calls an old soul.

Should it be:

He has what his father calls “an old soul.”

item.title: By: Cyber Monday: OK, Fine | Beeminder Blog
item.dc:creator: Cyber Monday: OK, Fine | Beeminder Blog
item.description: […] So much so that I can’t type it without derisive scare quotes. I personally am pretty allergic to “SAVE NOW!!”-style sales and coupons and whatnot. […]
